content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: <5 min... not for me!
I also suggest that this should be in easy puzzle.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: I have test it out and think its a nice problem, and it makes fun to solve. There are no bugs detected. In my opinion its not a good clash of code one, because it could take to much time to solve. But its a very good one as a puzzle, because it has much potential for optimization. Good work so far, thank you!

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Not an easy one but I've passed all tests in 5 minutes.
The statement is clear, I would also have added Shortest mode as it will give more time to solve it.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: A bit tough, but pretty much as easy as a sudoku solver could be. Solvable in 5 minutes.

Still seems too hard to me.

I had hoped that it was now all solvable by just iteratively checking rows and then columns for any that have a single "?" and then replacing it with the missing number.

This works for most tests, but currently fails the below:
'Corrupted Columns', Validator 2, 'All Lined Up', Validator 4, Validator 7.

It seems that the 'brute force' you say works actually needs to be a bit more smart?

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: It is good but not a type of coc which focuses on short and simple codes , maybe go for puzzle category
Simplified the clash according to the feedback given by @StepBack13 and @MindBoggles, hope it's more doable now.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: Honestly, it would be brilliant as a puzzle, but in Clash of code? I wouldn't say so, it would take too long to come up with a solution. I suggest that this should be in puzzle.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: This is honestly a bit too difficult for what its purpose here is. Even if one is already familiar with backtracking algorithms and comfortable with recursion (a lot of people might not be), it still takes a while to come up with a solution in a reasonable amount of time without having seen the problem from beforehand.

❌ Rejected the contribution.
Comment: This should be a CLASSIC PUZZLE (EASY) considering sub-grids are involved too... (Plus it is a good warm-up for other Sudoku puzzles with difficulty level of MEDIUM or above)

There is no way a user can solve it in less than 15 minutes. OTOH, it is relatively easy in Python due to a lot of built-in modules, which has been demonstrated in your solution, so don't use it as a metric for normalizing such tasks in COC overall...

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I found this puzzle to be very creative and enjoyed solving it. There were no issues I found while testing.
Agree with @StepBack13 that simplifying this slightly (no sub-grids) could make it better Clash of Code material, it feels slightly too hard for me but would feel perfect without subgrids.

Hey CodinGamer! Your contribution has unfortunately not been moderated on time and will temporarily be removed from the system... But no worries! You can republish it anytime to give it another chance! :)

This is a nice idea, but the subgrids make this too hard to solve in 5 minutes (especially for Reverse clashers who don't know Sudoku).

It took me about 7 minutes to solve for rows and columns, could have done it in 5 minutes if I was under the pressure of a clash perhaps, but I had to debug some things as I went.

Adding the subgrids would probably take me 12-18 minutes in total, I think.

I recommend just simplifying it so that you only need to use row and column logic to solve it, no subgrids.
The later test cases could be ones that can't be solve in a single 'pass' but rather need multiple passes of solving single rows or columns that are missing a single digit, which eventually leads to other rows and columns only having a single unsolved digit remaining.

Goal
* Consider changing "in one go" to "independently" to emphasise that each space can be solved without needing to solve other spaces first.

Cases
* Validator numbering: There's no Validator 2.

Thanks.
Done, thank you.

Thank you for your feedback! I agree that the sub-grids present a slightly harder challenge than if the sub-grid rule was omitted.

Not sure how I would communicate that there is no need to implement sub-grid checks to the Reverse clashers though. Clashers who do know Sudoku rules might be disadvantaged into trying to implement sub-grid checks. The test cases have been set up such that Sudoku-unaware clashers have a chance to learn the rules (referring especially to tests 5-7).

I had also set this puzzle to be one-pass only to spare clashers from having to implement loops and loop-breaking condition checks, which dilate from the original intent of this puzzle (to test how clashers would implement row-based, column-based, and subgrid-based checks).

Thanks for your feedback! Please also see my comments to @StepBack13.

Could you articulate the difficulty you faced when implemented sub-grid checks compared to solving for rows/columns?

There are already a number of Sudoku puzzles of various difficulty levels, so we don't need a similar one. (Search "Sudoku" under this topic: https://www.codingame.com/forum/t/puzzles-solvable-by-algorithm-x-dancing-links/196871 )
Thank you for your feedback! Just for your information, this clash can be solved without using backtracking at all! (that's what the constraints are for) :) But I can see why it might appear as such.
Have you tried writing a solution before going to that conclusion? Just asking.
Wait but that's exactly what my program does - iteratively checks each cell for being the only '?' in its row/column and replacing it with the missing number.
Thanks for the feedback! I didn't enable shortest mode as I didn't think players would enjoy having to code golf a clash that is slightly more difficult than usual.
No worries, thank you for your feedback :)
Oh oops, my code had an bug. Thanks for the quick reply.

yeah definitely man , i actually loved it , but we have to also look for learners who are there to play clash of code to learn , its a fun problem no doubt and i totally enjoyed while solving but i still think in coc it would be too much
Could you articulate the difficulty you faced when implemented sub-grid checks compared to solving for rows/columns?

The main difficulty is just that sub-grids are a lot more time-consuming to define. Rows are easy, columns are a bit harder but still pretty easy. With just rows and columns, you could solve this in around 5-8 minutes. Adding sub-grids is just too much for 5 minutes in my opinion. Like I said, it would probably take me 12 minutes minimum to do all three.

As for Reverse clashers, I think it would be natural to try just rows and columns first and see if it works before you attempt to solve sub-grids, so I don't think it's such a problem. You could also add a comment to the stub generator to warn Reverse clashers.

However, I think the simplest solution is to just remove sub-grids and also remove Reverse mode.
